channel.title: Hamsikaa हंसिका on Hamsikaa
channel.description: Recent content in Hamsikaa हंसिका on Hamsikaa

item.title: Verse 1
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures An Introduction to Aparokshanubhuti by Swami Sarvapriyananda (En) Notes How do we begin a text? As per custom, the text begins with an invocation to the Lord or Guru. What is the act Namami? - I bow down. Bowing is an act in becoming one with that to which we bow. It is as much about bhakti as it is about jñāna.

item.title: Verse 2
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Video URL Notes What are the contents of the book? - Aparokshanubhuti See Introduction for the meaning of Aparokshanubhuti What is the goal of the text? - To attain moksha, liberation Moksha is not a delayed supernatural gratification, but as an immediate and permanent cessation of suffering Who is the intended reader of the book?

item.title: Verse 3
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Lecture by Swami Sarvapriyananda (En) Notes How do we relate the different yogas to the path of Knowledge? To be ready for the reception of Knowledge, all other yogas are referenced in this verse: Karma - Dharma as per Varna and Ashrama Raja - Penance and austerities (of mind and body)

item.title: Verse 4
item.description: Reference material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda Lecture Notes Adi Shankaracharya starts with Vairagya as the first Sadhana Chatustayam. Usually, it begins with Viveka. Vairagya must be as strong to all aspects of the created world as is to the excreta of a crow. Adi Shankaracharya purposely brings about an analogy to a disgusting object. To today’s man, the world with its material desires seem important, but to the ancients the pleasures of a promised life in swarga (heaven) was more attractive.

item.title: Verse 5
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture Notes What is the meaning of Viveka? Viveka comes from the Sanskrit root विच् (to divide, to separate). So Viveka is about separating one thing from the other. Common analogies of Viveka Just as the ant is known to separate sugar from sand and the Swan separates milk from water. Shreya and Preya Life too provides us the mixture of that which is passing (temporal, often pleasurable) and that which is eternal (the divine, good).

item.title: Verse 6
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes What is षट्सम्पत्ति (six-fold wealth) of a spiritual seeker? शम (shama) दम (dama) श्रद्धा (shraddhaa) तितिक्षा (titikshaa) उपरति (uparati) समाधान (samadhaana) What is शम (shama)? It is the internal quietening of the mind. What is the root cause of lack of shama? Desires. The mind continuously runs behind desired objects losing its quiet internal balance.

item.title: Verse 7
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes What is उपरति (uparati)? Turning away from all sense objects is called uparati. It is the opposite of rati - which is enjoying the sense objects. Reversing the constant seeking of pleasure in the sense objects is called uparati. How does it relate to Sama and Dama? Uparati is a spontaneous disengagement from the external world.

item.title: Verse 8
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes What is श्रद्धा (shraddha)? Faith in the words of the Vedas or the teacher who expound the truth in the Vedas. This is called sabhda pramaana. Here, faith is implicit. What is समधान (samadhana)? The unwavering focus on the goal to be attained - enlightenment. This is the only real object that exists.

item.title: Verse 9
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes How should one’s desire be for liberation? Imagine a thief who knows there is gold in the next room with only a thin filament separating it. The desire of getting the gold is intense, so too the intensity of desire of a spiritual seeker. How are the 4 fold qualifications related?

item.title: Verse 10
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Who should take up this study? Only one who has worked to endow oneself with the said four-fold qualifications. What is to be done? An equiry into the nature of Reality or Self for the purpose of gaining knowledge. What is the motivation for doing this? Well-being of oneself.

item.title: Verse 11
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Relation to the earlier verse We have already been told that one wishing one’s own well-being should first be qualified with the four-fold qualification and then should take up vichAra for gaining of knowledge. In this verse, we are told about how vichAra is indispensable in the path of knowledge.

item.title: Verse 12
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Relation to previous verses The previous two verses have established the centrality of vichAra (spiritual enquiry) in the path of knowledge. This verse provides a methodology to this enquiry. What are the central questions to do vichAra on? The three central questions are on the topics of Jiva (creature, ourself), Jagat (Universe as perceived by us), and Ishvara (God).

item.title: Verse 13
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Relation to previous verses We set out the four important questions in the previous verse. Starting with this verse, answers are provided to these questions. This verse answers the first question - Who am I? What am I (not)? I am not a bhutagaNa - collection of elements or a mass of matter.

item.title: Verse 14
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Relation to previous verses We set out the four important questions in the 12th verse. This verse answers the second question - How did this universe come about? We are not concerned with the physical universe beginning say with the big bang. We are instead concerned about our own experience of this universe - Why is it that I am experiencing this phenomenal world?

item.title: Verse 15
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes What is the material cause? Upon inspection, a pot is found to be made up of clay or mud. Thus, the material cause is mud which has only been transformed by the efficient cause - the potter. The potter does not create material, he only transforms it. What is the material cause of ignorance and thought?

item.title: Verse 16
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Relation to the previous verses In verse 13, the nature of the Self was shown to be कश्चित् (kaschit) - something else. We now delve into this. What is the nature of Self? सूक्ष्म (sUkshma) or subtle - It is not an object of perception to the senses ज्ञाता (jJAtA) or knower - The knower of all perceptions साक्षी (sAkshI) or witness - The witness to all experience सत् (sat) or Existence - Unchanging, not subject to the six-fold change of existence, birth, growth, change, decay, death.

item.title: Verse 17
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Relation to the previous verses In verse 13, the nature of the Self was shown to be कश्चित् (kaschit) - something else. We now delve into defining this Self by removing parts that are not. Refinement Just as we refine the sludge to get petroleum out, so too we need to refine our notion of Self which is mixed with many dissimilar items.

item.title: Verse 18
item.description: Reference Material Video lectures Swami Sarvapriyananda lecture in En Notes Relation to the previous verses In the previous verse, the pointing out had started out of why we are not the body. This verse continues this. With respect to the function of control how do the Self and body relate? The body is controlled, and the Self (Atman) is the controller.

item.title: Changelog
item.description: 13th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 18 Moved site to Github pages 12th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 17 Added verse texts of all 143 verses 11th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 16 Added anvaya where available 9th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 15 Added recitation mode 8th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 14 7th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 13 6th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 11, 12 5th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verse 10 4th Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 8, 9 3rd Sep 2020 Aparokshanubhuti verses 1 through 7 2nd Sep 2020 Basic verse template stable with verse audio, text, meaning, word-by-word meaning, commentaries, and notes 28th Aug 2020 Website backend stable

item.description: Mahabharata Aparokshanubhuti
